facts.info: Iguanas are herbivores and eat mainly fruits, flowers, and leaves
There are over 40 species of iguanas, with the Green Iguana being the most common pet species
Iguanas can live up to 20 years in captivity
Iguanas are cold-blooded reptiles and require a warm environment to regulate their body temperature
The male iguana is called a 'bull' and the female is called a 'hen'
Iguanas have a third eye, called the parietal eye, on the top of their head that detects light and dark
Iguanas have strong jaws and sharp teeth, which they use to tear apart their food
The skin of an iguana is covered in small scales, which provide protection and help regulate their body temperature
Iguanas can change the color of their skin to better blend in with their surroundings or to communicate with other iguanas
Iguanas are excellent swimmers and can hold their breath for up to 30 minutes underwater
Iguanas are territorial and will defend their area against other iguanas, especially during mating season
Iguanas can run on their hind legs to escape predators
Iguanas have a specialized gland called the sublingual gland that secretes salt, allowing them to get rid of excess salt from their diet
The Green Iguana is the largest species of iguana, reaching up to 6 feet in length
Iguanas have a dewlap, a flap of skin under their chin, that they use to regulate their body temperature and to communicate with other iguanas
Iguanas are more active during the day and spend their nights sleeping in trees or on rocks
Iguanas are popular pets, but they require a lot of care and attention to stay healthy and happy
Iguanas have excellent eyesight and can detect movement from a long distance
Iguanas are able to regenerate their tails if they lose them to a predator or injury
Iguanas are not social animals and prefer to be alone, except during mating season
Iguanas have a unique digestive system that allows them to extract as much nutrition as possible from their food
Iguanas use their tails to help them balance when climbing and jumping
Iguanas are preyed upon by a variety of animals, including birds of prey, snakes, and wild cats
Iguanas are native to Central and South America, as well as some Caribbean islands
The spiny-tailed iguana has a tail covered in sharp spines that it uses to defend itself against predators
Iguanas have a special adaptation called the 'gular pump' that allows them to push air into their lungs when they swallow food
Iguanas have a unique way of communicating with other iguanas through head-bobbing and push-ups
Iguanas have long, sharp claws that help them climb and grip onto surfaces
Iguanas are diurnal animals, meaning they are most active during the day
Iguanas have a powerful tail that they can use as a whip to defend themselves against predators
Iguanas are able to detect changes in temperature, light, and sound through special sensory organs called 'saccules'
The rhinoceros iguana gets its name from the horn-like protrusions on its snout
Iguanas have a unique mating ritual that involves the male chasing and biting the female
Iguanas have a special adaptation in their intestines that allows them to extract water from their food, reducing their need for water
The iguana's scales are arranged in rings, which help protect its body from predators and environmental factors
Iguanas are able to sense changes in the Earth's magnetic field, which helps them navigate their environment
Iguanas have a specialized gland in their cloaca that releases a pheromone to attract mates
Iguanas are able to retract their eyes into their sockets for protection
Iguanas have a long, thin tongue that they use to sense their environment and locate food
The marine iguana is the only species of iguana that is able to swim in the ocean
Iguanas can fall up to 50 feet without being seriously injured due to their light weight and ability to land safely
Iguanas are cold-blooded animals, meaning their body temperature is regulated by their environment
Iguanas can live up to 20 years or more in the wild, and up to 30 years in captivity
Iguanas have been used in traditional medicine for centuries, with their meat, blood, and fat believed to have healing properties
Iguanas are social animals and can form strong bonds with their owners and other iguanas
Iguanas have a third 'parietal' eye on the top of their head, which is sensitive to light and helps regulate their sleep patterns
Iguanas have a specialized tongue that can detect different chemical compounds in the air, helping them locate food and avoid predators
Iguanas are able to change the color of their skin to blend in with their surroundings and regulate their body temperature
Iguanas have a complex hierarchy system, with dominant males competing for access to mates and resources
Iguanas are sometimes kept as pets, but require specialized care and can grow up to 6 feet in length
